Message re: Grenfell fire

Just see this posted xx

To people on here who want to help the Grenfell Tower crisis centres
If you can offer a bed to people in the Grenfell Tower fire and evacuated from buildings around, PLEASE EMAIL amanda.gill@rbkc.gov.uk
Nobody is accepting donations around here, at the moment
Don't come down
All the immediate help centres are "inundated", currently they do not know what they need
If people have something to offer then St Clements have asked you please leave name, number and what you can offer with me and I will take it to them in a couple of hours and they will call you direct when and if they need what you are offering.
Perhaps you can offer a family a bed for a night, or a place for their kids to watch telly nearby? Tesco has covered food and toilettries pretty well
Send your deepest love to this corner of London. There are many here who will desperately need it.

Debbie Groom

Conservative Headlines

Theresa May’s new chief of staff was responsible for delayed tower block fire safety review.

Theresa May’s New Advisor Gavin Barwell Failed To Review Tower Block Fire Regulations - Despite Four Years Of Warnings

Jeremy Corbyn tried to pass through a law that would required private landlords to make their homes safe and “fit for human habitation” last year – but it was rejected by the Conservatives.

Firefighters cried as 10 London stations including Clerkenwell closed due to cuts.

Residents of Grenfell Tower, which endured a raging fire on Wednesday 14 June, issued a stark warning that such an incident would occur after they alleged the landlord consistently failed to act on fire safety.

The landlord in charge of Grenfell Tower, where a fire broke out in the early hours on Wednesday 14 June, had been issued legal warnings over fire safety in two other tower blocks.
Grenfell Tower is owned by the council, the proposed Labour bill has no leverage in this discussion

It has been claimed that there is no building regulation requirement for external cladding to be fireproof...!
This though is irrelevant, because landlords have responsibilities under the HEALTH AND SAFETY AF WORK ETC ACT 1974, to ensure due care to all residents....
Here is a copy of a report findings prepared for the London Fire Brigade following concern over a previous fire...

" THE INVESTIGATION

Inside Housing has seen a report on the panels, compiled for the LFB by consultancy Bureau Veritas. It found:

The panels comprised a 17-23mm plywood board, covered by blue polystyrene foam, 1mm steel sheet and decorative white paint
When exposed to high flames, the polystyrene foam melted away, causing the metal sheet to fall and exposing the foam and wood to the flames
This is “likely” to have occurred to the panels above the flat where the fire started, with flaming droplets falling and flames spreading up
The experts concluded this is “likely to have assisted the fire in spreading up the outside of the building, as this mechanism progressively exposes a plywood surface to a developing fire”

DOES THAT SOYND LIKE THESE CLADDING PANELS CAN BE DEEMED TO MEET THE LEGAL REQUIREMENTS OF THE HSW ACT 1974? 
NO.!?

Been in external cladding 25 years ! And your right it doesn't have to be fireproof ! But adequate firestop / barrier must be fitted at each floor/ slab level horizontally ! This slows the spread of the fire allowing people to escape! It's a legal requirement to fit this ! From the video I've seen I would hazard a guess the firestop didn't work or was not installed correctly ! Of coarse this is just my humble opinion

Also to add I believe the system used on this building was an ACM which in lay men's terms is plastic covered each side with a 0.5 mm aluminium ! Not fireproof ! But as I said before in my opinion only !!! The fire spread to fast and to far for me ! Firestop more than likely not installed correctly

It is beyond comprehension that the safety of these tenants was not considered, and after reading more on this issue, I am sick... All those lives lost. Someone has to pay for this.. 
I read the council was nowhere to be seen, no aid nothing... They are uncaring. And everyone should be angered by this devastation RIP to all lives lost 😢😢😢

Car Ní Chon unfortunately if the council Clark of works is not on the ball then the install quality could have been overlooked and these works not signed off properly ! As I said in my opinion looking at how fast the fire spread the firestop didn't do its job ! Which can mean two things...it wasn't fitted correctly or even at all. Trust me if this found to be the case someone will face court and even prison
It's not good ! My thoughts are with the families of the unfortunate
I hope so Steven Cunnington, otherwise we are, all of us, our lives, worthless to these leeches, just commodity....  What a terrible horrible tragedy. 😥😢😩

Steven Cunnington.....Yes, the Health and Safety at Work etc Act 1974 is all encompassing, and there may well be a number of persons at fault through human error etc.
It's likely there are many contributory factors, including those matters you outline....but in Tower blocks firestorm and fire doors are commonly left open and abused.
....for me the cladding is a major factor which explains both the speed of spread, and the visual evidence on film....
....advice in case of fire under these circumstances was clearly inappropriate, and the such basic matter of failed fire alarms just added to the problems...
* I'm no expert on fire prevention, but in a former life I used to enforce the Health and Safety at Work etc Act 1974 amongst other legislation in a wide range of retail premises...

No amount of fire stop will prevent a fire spreading of the outside cladding had caught fire and is suitably combustible. The problem is cheap ACM panels which are just thin alum sheets either side of a plastic inner core. Decent ACM panel the inner core has a percentage of minerals and glue NOT plastic and is therefore much less combustible. Remains to be seen what happened here but this has been happening a lot in Dubai lately to so you can't just say it down to landlords. The fact remains that this building was returned last year (windows and cladding) at a cost of £2.6m, which is a fraction of the cost of a new build. The council own and cost will always be king. Don't make it right but it is fact. The only way you stop it is with an update to the regs. The issue described above from the other building is different, but the principles remain the same, sort the regs and then effectively manage the process

Wayne Hinsley...the panel construction might not be the same, but the principle is..these ones are added to insulate, and to tart property up, but don't necessarily meet an appropriate standard for fire test.
But I agree..we're talking rhe same thing here..Firstly the regs and standards need to be updated...don't tell the government though..this would be bureaucratic nonsense from Brussels!! 
Secondly, local authorities budgets are so squeezed by AUSTERITY, that finances are critical..Therefore they will take risks.
AT THE END OF THE DAY, IT COMES BACK TO POLITICS,.....
...and your sense of social justice and fairness....
...and what role you see the state having in ensuring health,  safety and welfare..
..leave if to the Tories, and they'll deregulate everything!

Wayne Hinsley horizontal firestop would have slowed the fire ! It's not designed to actually stop it just slow it ! But I see your point and know how ACM works ! There are minimum flammable properties that these panels must have ! Unlike in Saudi etc.. Where regs are non existent ! I've been looking today at the architects details ( sad git that I am ) and listening to witness accounts on the radio and TV my thoughts are no firestop around the windows could have contributed to the fast spread of the fire ! Basically with this kind of design what you are actually doing is creating a giant fire chimney ! With the massive wind resistants over such a distance the fire basically was helped along by the design ( over cladding an existing old structure ) weather it be firestop at slab level or around the windows ....this I'm sure played a part in the fires rapid spread . If it is found that cost cutting was to blame ....I wouldn't like to be in the architects or CDM guys shoes .

Can any of us imagine the total desparation that led to her and others making that decison ....did the Mum survive? May that child grow knowing it's mother, for sure, would lay down her life for her baby. Terrifying and awful and I don't have enough words of comfort for everyone involved. Lots of love <3

They cant get down properly because imagine... They need to go downstairs 24 floors full of smoke and fire...
